newsitem.title: GERMANY: Prosecutor completes probe into tycoon Schneider.
newsitem.headline: Prosecutor completes probe into tycoon Schneider.

text.p: The Frankfurt state prosecutors' office said on Friday it had completed an investigation into property tycoon Juergen Schneider and would announce details at a news conference on Monday.
Prosecutors allege that Schneider committed fraud relating to the spectacular collapse of his property empire under debts of more than five billion marks ($3.25 billion) in 1994.

The prosecutors' office said in December it would file formal fraud charges against Schneider in early January. A spokesman for the office declined to say on Friday whether Schneider had already been charged.
One of the tycoon's lawyers, Christoph Rueckel, said last month Schneider would be formally charged with fraud and credit fraud as well as falsifying documents and fraudulent bankruptcy.
Schneider, who is being held in jail, bought some of Germany's most prestigious real estate in the post-unification property boom.
But he slid toward bankruptcy because the rental income was too small to finance huge debts he took on to buy the properties.
Schneider fled the country in April 1994 with his wife Claudia, abandoning his troubled property group. Prosecutors allege he obtained credit on the basis of falsified documents.
The Schneiders were detained in Miami in 1995 after a year-long international manhunt. They returned voluntarily to Germany last February to face questioning.
Claudia Schneider, who has been freed from prison on conditional release amid concerns about her health, is expected to be charged with being an accessory to bankruptcy.
Two former associates, Mehdi Djawadi, alleged to have helped the Schneiders plan their getaway, and Karl-Heinrich Kuepferle are also expected to be charged.
Frankfurt prosecutors have said the trial is unlikely to begin before mid-1997. (1=1.5462 Mark)
